awd_titl_txt: Health Care Providers and Patient Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
SES - 1226416
Mary Campbell
Ellen Franklin
Amal Rahhal
University of Iowa

Abstract

Health Care Providers and Patient Interactions

This project builds on extant research showing that demographic characteristics impact most social interactions and a range of life course outcomes.  Debate continues about the impact of phenotypical differences on the quality of interactions in the health care context.  To that end, the project examines how patient characteristics affect interactions with health care providers. The central hypothesis being tested is whether the content and quality of interactions between health care providers and their patients is indeed affected by phenotype and skin tone. The study permits comparisons not only between racial groups (e.g., whites and African Americans) but also within racial groups (e.g., darker- vs. lighter-skinned African Americans and Latino/as). To test this hypothesis, the project relies on field experiment methods. Specifically, videotapes of medical students practicing medical history interviews with "standardized patients" (actors) will be analyzed for both verbal and nonverbal interaction dynamics. The benefit of this field experiment is that it takes place in a realistic setting rather than a lab and yet it still provides a standardized encounter in a similar environment. Analysis methods include quantitative modeling (HLM).

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this research may inform our understanding of how individual-level interactions, in addition to well-understood factors like access to health insurance or preventative care, influence group disparities in health outcomes.  Findings may be of interest not only to policy makers but to insurance providers, the medical community and medical schools charged with developing training, assessment, and intervention programs.  The project also broadens the participation of underrepresented groups and students in STEM-related research.

por.por_cntn:
Research on communication between health care providers and their patients has shown significant inequalities in the quality of interactions. Past research in clinical settings has shown, for example, that female patients often receive more information than male patients, female physicians often talk more with their patients than male physicians, and white patients often benefit from more patient-centered interactions than patients of color.

This project used a video recorded field experiment to test how the social characteristics of standardized patients (actors) and medical students affected the quality of their interaction in a controlled setting. We collected and coded video recordings of medical students conducting medical history interviews as part of a course during their first year of medical school, examining their verbal and nonverbal behaviors. We also asked both the standardized patients and the medical students to report their feelings about the interaction, such as how comfortable and calm they were in the interaction and how well the standardized patients felt the medical students listened to them. This project advanced knowledge by demonstrating how social characteristics such as gender, racial/ethnic group and skin color are related to interaction quality in a setting that is realistic but where many of the factors that affect the quality of interactions between doctors and patients are controlled (for example, without the time pressures found in real clinical settings, without differences between patients in the type of illness they have, and without the ability of patients and health care providers to choose to interact only with certain people). Data analysis is ongoing for some outcomes, such as the nonverbal behaviors displayed in the interactions. Results so far have shown that the personal characteristics of the medical student and the patient (actor) have important relationships with both the observed characteristics of the interaction – such as how much time the medical student and patient each spent talking – as well as the subjective experience of both interaction partners – such as how comfortable they each felt during the interaction. For example, our analysis has shown that patients paired with medical students of color were more likely to report that they did not feel comfortable or calm in the interaction, and that the student did not listen to them as well, even though objective measures of the interaction did not show that medical students of color conducted shorter interviews or asked fewer medically-focused questions. Conversely, when standardized patients of color or darker skinned patients were in the interaction, those interactions were more likely to have the medical student talk more and the patient talk less.

This research will have a broader impact because it demonstrates the importance of teaching medical students techniques to overcome unconscious differences in how patients with different social characteristics are treated. The dissemination of the results will help medical schools expand their training in innovative ways, demonstrating that how social statuses are perceived has an impact on the subjective experience of the interaction as well as the objective measures of the interaction.

We have presented preliminary results from this project at two peer-reviewed academic conferences, and expect at least two peer-reviewed publications to result from this work.
